He has not yet had an endoscopy or barium study performed. He is developmentally delayed due to the surgery, panhypopituitarism. His family history is significant for his father being of mine, also having reflux issues, without true heartburn, but distal esophageal stricture. The patient does not smoke, does not drink. layman:
**Procedures Performed:**  
Upper endoscopy (esophagogastroduodenoscopy).

**Pre‑procedure Diagnosis:**  
Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia).

**Post‑procedure Diagnosis:**  
Active acid reflux causing inflammation of the esophagus, narrowing in the lower esophagus (stricture), a ring‑like narrowing from reflux, and the narrowing was widened with a balloon to 18 mm.

**Procedure Details:**  
The patient gave informed consent after the doctor explained the benefits, risks, and alternatives. Risks mentioned included bleeding, infection, a hole in the bowel, pneumonia from inhaling food or liquid, and reactions to the medications. Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen levels were monitored, and extra oxygen was given. The doctor talked through the steps of the procedure with the patient’s parents because the patient has a mental disability. The patient usually has trouble swallowing solids, swallows liquids better, and the problem has gotten worse over the last six months. He had an emergency department visit last year and went to the ED yesterday after eating beef jerky. All of this was reviewed.

The patient is taking Cortef, Synthroid, Tegretol, Norvasc, lisinopril, and DDAVP. He has a long medical history that includes brain surgery for an astrocytoma, hypothyroidism, and hormone deficiency. He has not had a full work‑up yet, and he has never had an endoscopy or a barium swallow test. He has developmental delays from the brain surgery and has panhypopituitarism. His father also has reflux problems and a narrowing in the lower esophagus, but no heartburn. The patient does not smoke or drink and lives with his parents. Since his ED visit yesterday, he has had no major complaints. He is a large male, not in acute distress. Vital signs were checked in the endoscopy room. His lungs were clear, his heart rhythm was regular, his abdomen was soft but large, and his hands were large. He had a Mallampati score of A and an ASA classification of type 2.

The doctor discussed the procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives with the patient and his mother. Possible other causes of swallowing difficulty, such as a motility disorder related to his brain surgery or conditions like achalasia, were mentioned. The need for a barium swallow or a modified barium swallow was also discussed. All questions were answered. The plan is to perform the endoscopy to evaluate the swallowing problem, with the possibility of dilating the narrowing if needed. He may have reflux symptoms even without heartburn and might benefit from a trial of a proton‑pump inhibitor. All was reviewed and all questions answered.
